Proposal #: 11-26393 (Consortium) 11-26747
PI(s): Bastani, Farokh & Tian, Jeff
Gupta, Gopal; Huynh, Dung T.; Yen, I-Ling & Huang, LiGuo; Nair, Sukumaran
Institution: University of Texas-Dallas; & Southern Methodist University
Title: MRI Consortium/Dev.: Instrumentation for Measuring the Dependability and Quality of Cloud Computing Systems
Project Proposed:
This project, aiming to develop instrumentation that enables rigorous experimental quality and dependability assessment of cloud computing systems, including cloud service-oriented architecture
(SOA) systems, dramatically enhances the validation capability of cloud platform services and cyberinfrastructure. Cloud platforms must meet specified service level agreements (SLA) and provide mechanisms to support the minimization of the power used in cloud data centers without adversely affecting the quality of service (QoS). Also, some safety-critical emerging cloud applications, such as health-care and transportation applications, must meet stringent dependability requirements, that include high availability, reliability, performance, resilience, safety, and security. The proposed work establishes a high performance, metrics-driven instrument enabling rigorous evaluation for the following research projects on cloud performance:
- Assurance of QoS in Service Clouds,
- Optimization of Dependability in Evolving Clouds,
- Mobile Device Power Management in Service Clouds,
- Achievement of Highly Secure Compositions in Service Clouds, and
- Testing and Validation of Secure Hardware-Software Architectures.
The work aims to develop a flexible instrument for validation and verification of cloud performance, seen to be a key element in the future of computing services. In recent years, computer services have been moving to remote virtual machines ?in the cloud.? The commercial success of this new business model is based on service quality guarantees, which are becoming increasingly hard to verify as the complexity and volume of cloud services increase. Testbeds of this type are critical to the economic and research vitality of the academic and industrial communities.
Broader Impacts:
This instrumentation substantially raises the quality, scale, and scope of experimental research in dependability enhancement methods for cloud computing systems. It helps foster a strong scientifically based experimental paradigm for computing and provides capabilities that will greatly enhance the quality of undergraduate and graduate courses in computer science and engineering, as well as senior design projects by enabling students to work on realistic platforms. The instrumentation enhances the facilities of an NSF I/UCRC and will be available to researchers at the participating institutions and industrial partners.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cloud Dependability Measurement Instrument

 

This MRI project has led to the development of a Cloud Dependability Monitoring Instrument (CDMI) for measuring the dependability of cloud computing systems. CDMI has a monitor-analyzer architecture which facilitates on-the-fly analysis of various dependability attributes of cloud computing systems and mitigation of any adverse operational conditions.

The monitoring data repository in CDMI is based on a Semantically Enhanced Round Robin Database (SE-RRD) model. Many monitoring systems use proprietary repositories to store monitoring data, making it difficult to interoperate with various dependability analysis tools. RRD (Round Robin Database) intends to setup a standard for monitoring data repositories and the corresponding RRDTool offers interface functions for accessing the RRD monitoring data. The RRDTool is widely used in many cloud monitoring systems. Though it offers efficient monitoring data storage and retrieval, it is deficient in specifying the semantics of the monitoring data. In this MRI project, the RRDTool has been used as the basis and its semantics have been substantially enhanced to create the SE-RRDTool. An upper level ontology model has been developed to guide the semantic specifications of monitoring data streams in SE-RRD. The SE-RRDTool has been developed to incorporate the ontology model and an ontology-based reasoning engine has been developed to support rich specifications of monitoring data streams. (The SE-RRDTool is now published on GitHub.)

Due to the use of SE-RRD, cloud dependability analysis, diagnosis, and mitigation tools in CDMI can easily interoperate with the monitoring repository. Different data specifications can be mapped to SE-RRD via the reasoning engine in the SE-RRDTool. Also, SE-RRDTool supports semantic-based monitoring data retrieval. An important advantage of this is that users do not need to know how and in which file the monitoring data streams of interests are stored and can retrieve them via the specification of their semantics in the retrieval queries.

CDMI also offers a cloud experimentation environment, including a set of cloud benchmarking programs and a suite of dependability evaluation components. This enables researchers to plug in their dependability algorithms into the system and rapidly configure the CDMI monitors and benchmark applications to evaluate the effectiveness of their solutions.

Many students have actively participated in the development and usage of the CDMI system, including several graduate students and also some undergraduate students in our research group and students in Cloud Computing courses over the five year period during which the instrument was developed. This cloud dependability measurement instrument is very important given the rapidly increasing use of cloud computing systems in numerous emerging critical applications and it will continue to be enhanced and used for research and teaching.
